know_passage: Models and simulations also eliminate the 'gross-out factor' of animal dissection, such as smelly, slimy real dead frogs, allowing students to focus on the learning activity rather than nausea. [22] [23]

passage_ori: Models and simulations also eliminate the “gross-out factor” of smelly, slimy real dead frogs, allowing students to focus on the learning activity rather than nausea. [22] [23]

know_passage: Synthetic frogs made by SynDaver have the same visual and textural qualities as a deceased female frog: skeletons with muscles, skin, and organs, including a reproductive system with eggs. They also address ethical concerns surrounding traditional dissection. The models can be reused year-after-year and don’t need toxic formaldehyde for preservation. However, parental attitudes towards dissection may still undermine acceptance of these alternatives.

passage_ori: Synthetic frogs made by SynDaver have the same visual and textural qualities as a dead female frog: skeletons with muscles, skin, and organs, including a reproductive system with eggs. know_passage: According to a meta-review by the Humane Society, students learn just as well or better when models and computer simulations are substituted for dead animals. [22] [23]
